elements.content: To develop a tunable assembly of metal ions, we demonstrated a two-dimensional Ag(I) array in the crystalline state by using an assembly of dipeptide ligands as a template. The two-dimensional assembly of Ag(I) ions was obtained through the assembly of a Ag(I)-peptide polymer complex, which was held together by hydrogen bonding interactions. At –180 °C, one-dimensional zigzag chains of Ag(I) ions were formed in each layer, which further assembled to form two-dimensional layers. The arrangement of the Ag(I) ions included several Ag–Ag distances that are supported differently by the peptide assembly. Because of this difference, when heated from –180 to 50 °C, the Ag(I) layer displays anisotropic thermal expansion in the arrangements, in which one of the Ag–Ag distances selectively elongated. This expansion is reversible, allowing switching between the zigzag chain assembly and the Ag(I) dimer assembly. Moreover, the resulting crystalline Ag(I) complexes show luminescence at both room temperature and at –196 °C, suggesting the existence of Ag–Ag interactions.
elements.clean_text: To develop a tunable assembly of metal ions, we demonstrated a two-dimensional Ag(I) array in the crystalline state by using an assembly of dipeptide ligands as a template. The two-dimensional assembly of Ag(I) ions was obtained through the assembly of a Ag(I)-peptide polymer complex, which was held together by hydrogen bonding interactions. At -180 °C, one-dimensional zigzag chains of Ag(I) ions were formed in each layer, which further assembled to form two-dimensional layers. The arrangement of the Ag(I) ions included several Ag-Ag distances that are supported differently by the peptide assembly. Because of this difference, when heated from -180 to 50 °C, the Ag(I) layer displays anisotropic thermal expansion in the arrangements, in which one of the Ag-Ag distances selectively elongated. This expansion is reversible, allowing switching between the zigzag chain assembly and the Ag(I) dimer assembly. Moreover, the resulting crystalline Ag(I) complexes show luminescence at both room temperature and at -196 °C, suggesting the existence of Ag-Ag interactions.

elements.content: A two-dimensional Ag­(I) array in the crystalline state was demonstrated by using an assembly of dipeptide ligands as a template. The arrangements of Ag­(I) ions presented selective thermal expansion of the Ag−Ag distances, correlating with the hydrogen bonds between the template peptides.
elements.clean_text: A two-dimensional Ag(I) array in the crystalline state was demonstrated by using an assembly of dipeptide ligands as a template. The arrangements of Ag(I) ions presented selective thermal expansion of the Ag-Ag distances, correlating with the hydrogen bonds between the template peptides.

elements.content: The assembly of metal ions is one of the most powerful tools for designing solid-state functionalities such as luminescence and conductivity based on the arrangements of the metal ions. In particular, d10 metal ions (such as Au­(I), Ag­(I), and Cu­(I)) can assemble in such a way so as to enable multiple interactions between metal centers because of their low coordination number and favored interactions between metal ions (such as d10–d10 interactions). In fact, simple Ag­(I) complexes (simple salt, silver benzenesulfonate, silver pyridine-2-thiolate, and others) are well-known to show two-dimensional (2D) assemblies and demonstrate various interesting properties (e.g., red-shift to the visible region, emissions, and semiconductive properties), which are very sensitive to molecular arrangements. Although the use of a template (such as designable ligands) is useful to control the arrangements of the metal ions, in many reports, the assemblies of Ag­(I) ions have been limited to one-dimensional arrangements, i.e., linear, or cluster arrangements, because the steric hindrance of the ligands often prevents further metal arrangements. For templates to achieve designable and dense 2D arrangements, we focused on the assembled sheet structure of peptides, which are assembled with the appropriate distances for direct metal–metal interactions. In addition, anisotropic switching of the interactions would be expected due to the directional interactions between the peptides, because crystalline peptide complexes can undergo conformational and/or structural changes under external stimuli. Herein, we report a novel 2D assembly of Ag­(I) ions in the crystalline state using peptide bridging ligands. The 2D arrangements have several Ag­(I) contacts with different Ag–Ag distances, and they demonstrate different thermal expansion correlated to the hydrogen bonding interactions in the template peptide (Figure ). The Ag­(I) assembly also demonstrates luminescence at room temperature.
elements.clean_text: The assembly of metal ions is one of the most powerful tools for designing solid-state functionalities such as luminescence and conductivity based on the arrangements of the metal ions. In particular, d10 metal ions (such as Au(I), Ag(I), and Cu(I)) can assemble in such a way so as to enable multiple interactions between metal centers because of their low coordination number and favored interactions between metal ions (such as d10-d10 interactions). In fact, simple Ag(I) complexes (simple salt, silver benzenesulfonate, silver pyridine-2-thiolate, and others) are well-known to show two-dimensional (2D) assemblies and demonstrate various interesting properties (e.g., red-shift to the visible region, emissions, and semiconductive properties), which are very sensitive to molecular arrangements. Although the use of a template (such as designable ligands) is useful to control the arrangements of the metal ions, in many reports, the assemblies of Ag(I) ions have been limited to one-dimensional arrangements, i.e., linear, or cluster arrangements, because the steric hindrance of the ligands often prevents further metal arrangements. For templates to achieve designable and dense 2D arrangements, we focused on the assembled sheet structure of peptides, which are assembled with the appropriate distances for direct metal-metal interactions. In addition, anisotropic switching of the interactions would be expected due to the directional interactions between the peptides, because crystalline peptide complexes can undergo conformational and/or structural changes under external stimuli. Herein, we report a novel 2D assembly of Ag(I) ions in the crystalline state using peptide bridging ligands. The 2D arrangements have several Ag(I) contacts with different Ag-Ag distances, and they demonstrate different thermal expansion correlated to the hydrogen bonding interactions in the template peptide (Figure ). The Ag(I) assembly also demonstrates luminescence at room temperature.

elements.content: (a) Synthetic scheme of the Ag­(I)-helical complex of dipeptide ligand 1, and (b) the assembled structure of Ag­(I) ions in the crystal structure of Ag­(I) complexes; Ag­(I) ions are shown as space-filling models for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Synthetic scheme of the Ag(I)-helical complex of dipeptide ligand 1, and (b) the assembled structure of Ag(I) ions in the crystal structure of Ag(I) complexes; Ag(I) ions are shown as space-filling models for clarity.

elements.content: We first designed and synthesized dipeptide 1 as a bridging ligand (Figure a). Two derivatives of natural amino acids, asparagine acid and an asparagine derivative, were used for the N-terminus and C terminus of dipeptide 1, respectively. We intended to reduce the steric hindrance between ligands by designing simple coordinating sites both at the side chain and at the main chain. Thus, dipeptide 1 possesses two coordinating sites both at the N-terminus and C-terminus: carboxylate groups as the anionic binding site and amino groups. Thereby, 1 would be expected to form a neutral complex with one M2+ ion or two M+ ions, which could assemble closely in the crystalline state and provide contacts or interactions between metal ions. Furthermore, amino groups and carboxylate groups can form up to two hydrogen bonds that could contribute to the high dimensional assembly of 1 as a template.
elements.clean_text: We first designed and synthesized dipeptide 1 as a bridging ligand (Figure a). Two derivatives of natural amino acids, asparagine acid and an asparagine derivative, were used for the N-terminus and C terminus of dipeptide 1, respectively. We intended to reduce the steric hindrance between ligands by designing simple coordinating sites both at the side chain and at the main chain. Thus, dipeptide 1 possesses two coordinating sites both at the N-terminus and C-terminus: carboxylate groups as the anionic binding site and amino groups. Thereby, 1 would be expected to form a neutral complex with one M2+ ion or two M+ ions, which could assemble closely in the crystalline state and provide contacts or interactions between metal ions. Furthermore, amino groups and carboxylate groups can form up to two hydrogen bonds that could contribute to the high dimensional assembly of 1 as a template.

elements.content: Dipeptide ligand 1 was prepared by coupling the derivatives of asparagine acid 2 and asparagine 3, possessing the appropriate protecting groups, under microwave radiation (Scheme S1 in ). Following the removal of the Boc groups, dipeptide ligand 1 was obtained as a colorless form in 80% yields.
elements.clean_text: Dipeptide ligand 1 was prepared by coupling the derivatives of asparagine acid 2 and asparagine 3, possessing the appropriate protecting groups, under microwave radiation (Scheme S1 in ). Following the removal of the Boc groups, dipeptide ligand 1 was obtained as a colorless form in 80% yields.

elements.content: The reaction of dipeptide 1 with Ag (ClO4)·H2O in a 1:2 molecular ratio in the presence of DIEA as a base in water produced [1 2–Ag2] n as a colorless crystal in a 69% yield after slow evaporation of the solvent. In the resulting crystal structure, the Ag­(I) complex is crystallized in the monoclinic chiral space group P21 with (1 2–)­Ag2 asymmetric units (Figure a). In each Ag­(I) center, a linear coordination was formed between the amino group and carboxylate group; that is, dipeptide ligand 1 binds with the Ag­(I) ion in its deprotonated form (1 2–). The coordination sites of the N-terminus are connected with those of the C-terminus of the neighboring peptide by combination of the amino and carboxylate group. As a result, the deprotonated dipeptide ligand (1 2–) connected in a head-to-tail manner and formed an infinite right-handed helix [(1 2–)­Ag2] n (from N-terminus to C-terminus: Figure ). The Ag­(I)-peptide polymer complex (Ag­(I) helical complex) interacts with neighboring complexes through hydrogen bonding between the dipeptide ligands to form an assembled sheet structure along both the a and c axes (Figure a). On the basis of the distances in the crystal structure, it was found that there are three and two hydrogen bonds per dipeptide for the a and c axes, respectively (Figure b–d). Along the a axis, a peptide backbone was assembled through hydrogen bonding between the amide groups and the coordination sites (amino group and carboxylate group of 1) to form a parallel sheet structure. Furthermore, along the c axis, a sheet-like assembly of peptides was obtained through further hydrogen bonding between the coordination sites: both amino groups of 1 form two hydrogen bonding interactions with different neighboring dipeptides to form the three-dimensional (3D) assembled structure. Moreover, Ag­(I) ions in the peptide assembly are located very close to Ag­(I) ions in the neighboring helix, within distances where Ag–Ag interactions are expected: 3.16 Å for Ag(1)–Ag(2)#1 and 3.20 Å for Ag(1)–Ag(2)#2 (solid lines in Figure a, symmetry code: #1:1 + x, y, 1 + z; #2:1 + x, y, z). Consequently, one-dimensional (1D) zigzag Ag(I) chains are formed along the c axis (Figures and a). The 1D zigzag Ag­(I) chains are layered along the a axis at the distance of Ag­(I) ions bridged by the bidentate coordinating sites of 1 (3.47 Å: Ag(1)–Ag(2), dashed line in Figure a) to form a 2D-sheet structure that lies parallel to the a, c plane (also refer to Figure S5 in ). These Ag–Ag distances are supported differently by the assembled peptide; for instance, there are no hydrogen bonds between the helical complexes bridged by Ag(1)–Ag(2)#1 (Figure d), while Ag(1)–Ag(2)#2 and Ag(1)–Ag(2) are supported by three hydrogen bonds between the peptides (Figure c) and the ligand, respectively.
elements.clean_text: The reaction of dipeptide 1 with Ag (ClO4)⋅H2O in a 1:2 molecular ratio in the presence of DIEA as a base in water produced [1 2-Ag2] n  as a colorless crystal in a 69% yield after slow evaporation of the solvent. In the resulting crystal structure, the Ag(I) complex is crystallized in the monoclinic chiral space group P21 with (1 2-)Ag2 asymmetric units (Figure a). In each Ag(I) center, a linear coordination was formed between the amino group and carboxylate group; that is, dipeptide ligand 1 binds with the Ag(I) ion in its deprotonated form (1 2-). The coordination sites of the N-terminus are connected with those of the C-terminus of the neighboring peptide by combination of the amino and carboxylate group. As a result, the deprotonated dipeptide ligand (1 2-) connected in a head-to-tail manner and formed an infinite right-handed helix [(1 2-)Ag2] n  (from N-terminus to C-terminus: Figure ). The Ag(I)-peptide polymer complex (Ag(I) helical complex) interacts with neighboring complexes through hydrogen bonding between the dipeptide ligands to form an assembled sheet structure along both the a and c axes (Figure a). On the basis of the distances in the crystal structure, it was found that there are three and two hydrogen bonds per dipeptide for the a and c axes, respectively (Figure b-d). Along the a axis, a peptide backbone was assembled through hydrogen bonding between the amide groups and the coordination sites (amino group and carboxylate group of 1) to form a parallel sheet structure. Furthermore, along the c axis, a sheet-like assembly of peptides was obtained through further hydrogen bonding between the coordination sites: both amino groups of 1 form two hydrogen bonding interactions with different neighboring dipeptides to form the three-dimensional (3D) assembled structure. Moreover, Ag(I) ions in the peptide assembly are located very close to Ag(I) ions in the neighboring helix, within distances where Ag-Ag interactions are expected: 3.16 Å for Ag(1)-Ag(2)#1 and 3.20 Å for Ag(1)-Ag(2)#2 (solid lines in Figure a, symmetry code: #1:1 + x, y, 1 + z; #2:1 + x, y, z). Consequently, one-dimensional (1D) zigzag Ag(I) chains are formed along the c axis (Figures  and a). The 1D zigzag Ag(I) chains are layered along the a axis at the distance of Ag(I) ions bridged by the bidentate coordinating sites of 1 (3.47 Å: Ag(1)-Ag(2), dashed line in Figure a) to form a 2D-sheet structure that lies parallel to the a, c plane (also refer to Figure S5 in ). These Ag-Ag distances are supported differently by the assembled peptide; for instance, there are no hydrogen bonds between the helical complexes bridged by Ag(1)-Ag(2)#1 (Figure d), while Ag(1)-Ag(2)#2 and Ag(1)-Ag(2) are supported by three hydrogen bonds between the peptides (Figure c) and the ligand, respectively.

elements.content: Crystal structures of the Ag­(I) complex ([(1 2–)Ag2] n ) with atomic numbering (a) from the side view along the a axis, and (b) from the top view along the b axis. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 2  Crystal structures of the Ag(I) complex ([(1 2-)Ag2] n ) with atomic numbering (a) from the side view along the a axis, and (b) from the top view along the b axis. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: Crystal structure showing the 2D assembly of Ag­(I) ions accompanied by the formation of the peptide sheet structure along the b axis (a) and its side view showing the relationship of neighboring peptide ligands along the a axis (b), the c axis (c), and the bisector of angle β (d). Neighboring Ag­(I) helical complexes are colored green (along the a axis), pink (along the c axis), and blue (along the bisector of angle β). Dashed lines in (b) and (c) represent short contacts which suggest hydrogen bond formation. Symmetry codes: #1: 1 + x, y, 1 + z, #2: 1 + x, y, z.
elements.clean_text: 3  Crystal structure showing the 2D assembly of Ag(I) ions accompanied by the formation of the peptide sheet structure along the b axis (a) and its side view showing the relationship of neighboring peptide ligands along the a axis (b), the c axis (c), and the bisector of angle β (d). Neighboring Ag(I) helical complexes are colored green (along the a axis), pink (along the c axis), and blue (along the bisector of angle β). Dashed lines in (b) and (c) represent short contacts which suggest hydrogen bond formation. Symmetry codes: #1: 1 + x, y, 1 + z, #2: 1 + x, y, z.

elements.content: To investigate the changes in the Ag­(I) arrangement depending on external stimuli, we studied the thermal expansion behavior by increasing the temperature from −180 to 50 °C. Because of the differences in Ag–Ag distances described above, the Ag–Ag distances show completely different thermal expansion behaviors (Figure and ). Ag(1)–Ag(2)#1 maintains an almost constant Ag–Ag distance (within ca. 0.02 Å), although it is not supported directly by hydrogen bonds. In contrast, the distance of Ag(1)–Ag(2)#2 increases up to 3.36 Å (+0.15 Å), thereby exceeding the length corresponding to Ag–Ag interactions (i.e., 3.3 Å) between −50 to 0 °C (Table S3 in ). The distance of Ag(1)–Ag(2) bridged by the ligand also remains almost constant (with in ca. 0.01 Å). Subsequently, the 1D zigzag chains transform into a dimer assembly, as shown in Figure b, with expansion along the c axis (also refer to ). The difference in the thermal expansion of Ag–Ag contacts (6.7 times: 0.15 Å (+4.7%) versus 0.02 Å (+0.7%)) is much larger than those observed for the previously reported 2D layer of d10 metal ions (<2 times). In contrast to the changes in Ag(1)–Ag(2)#2, the N–O distances between peptide ligands, which suggest hydrogen bond formation, maintain their structure within ±0.05 Å, except for distances between N(3)–O(4) (Table S4 and Figure S6 in ). Considering Ag–Ag interactions are normally weaker than hydrogen bonding interactions, these results suggest that the conformational changes of the assembled peptide with intact hydrogen bonds would result in selective thermal expansion in Ag(I) arrangements (i.e., Ag(1)–Ag(2)#2). Therefore, a hydrogen-bond network between the dipeptide ligands is probably essential for selective elongation of the Ag–Ag distances. In addition to these changes in the Ag­(I) arrangements, anisotropic expansion was also observed for the crystal packing structure. Upon increasing the temperature from −180 to 50 °C, the crystal cell itself showed anisotropic expansion along the c axis (+0.5%, +0.2%, and +1.4% along the a, b, and c axis, respectively, refer to Figures S3 and S4 in ), which is in agreement with the fact that the number of suggested hydrogen bonding interactions are larger for the a axis (3 per peptide) than the c axis (2 per peptide).
elements.clean_text: To investigate the changes in the Ag(I) arrangement depending on external stimuli, we studied the thermal expansion behavior by increasing the temperature from -180 to 50 °C. Because of the differences in Ag-Ag distances described above, the Ag-Ag distances show completely different thermal expansion behaviors (Figure  and ). Ag(1)-Ag(2)#1 maintains an almost constant Ag-Ag distance (within ca. 0.02 Å), although it is not supported directly by hydrogen bonds. In contrast, the distance of Ag(1)-Ag(2)#2 increases up to 3.36 Å (+0.15 Å), thereby exceeding the length corresponding to Ag-Ag interactions (i.e., 3.3 Å) between -50 to 0 °C (Table S3 in ). The distance of Ag(1)-Ag(2) bridged by the ligand also remains almost constant (with in ca. 0.01 Å). Subsequently, the 1D zigzag chains transform into a dimer assembly, as shown in Figure b, with expansion along the c axis (also refer to ). The difference in the thermal expansion of Ag-Ag contacts (6.7 times: 0.15 Å (+4.7%) versus 0.02 Å (+0.7%)) is much larger than those observed for the previously reported 2D layer of d10 metal ions (<2 times). In contrast to the changes in Ag(1)-Ag(2)#2, the N-O distances between peptide ligands, which suggest hydrogen bond formation, maintain their structure within ±0.05 Å, except for distances between N(3)-O(4) (Table S4 and Figure S6 in ). Considering Ag-Ag interactions are normally weaker than hydrogen bonding interactions, these results suggest that the conformational changes of the assembled peptide with intact hydrogen bonds would result in selective thermal expansion in Ag(I) arrangements (i.e., Ag(1)-Ag(2)#2). Therefore, a hydrogen-bond network between the dipeptide ligands is probably essential for selective elongation of the Ag-Ag distances. In addition to these changes in the Ag(I) arrangements, anisotropic expansion was also observed for the crystal packing structure. Upon increasing the temperature from -180 to 50 °C, the crystal cell itself showed anisotropic expansion along the c axis (+0.5%, +0.2%, and +1.4% along the a, b, and c axis, respectively, refer to Figures S3 and S4 in ), which is in agreement with the fact that the number of suggested hydrogen bonding interactions are larger for the a axis (3 per peptide) than the c axis (2 per peptide).

elements.content: Since Ag–Ag interactions are well-known to produce emission, we examined the emission behavior of the crystals. As shown in Figure , emission of the Ag­(I) complex was clearly observed at 77 K (−196 °C), suggesting the existence of interactions between Ag­(I) ions. Even at the room temperature, emission was observed, although the intensity was weakened (Figures , ). On the other hand, emission spectra varied between room temperature and 77 K (), suggesting that the interactions around Ag­(I) ions changed depending on the temperature.
elements.clean_text: Since Ag-Ag interactions are well-known to produce emission, we examined the emission behavior of the crystals. As shown in Figure , emission of the Ag(I) complex was clearly observed at 77 K (-196 °C), suggesting the existence of interactions between Ag(I) ions. Even at the room temperature, emission was observed, although the intensity was weakened (Figures , ). On the other hand, emission spectra varied between room temperature and 77 K (), suggesting that the interactions around Ag(I) ions changed depending on the temperature.

elements.content: Photographs of the Ag­(I) complex ([(1 2–)Ag2] n ) under irradiation of 365 nm light at room temperature (left) and at 77 K (right).
elements.clean_text: 5  Photographs of the Ag(I) complex ([(1 2-)Ag2] n ) under irradiation of 365 nm light at room temperature (left) and at 77 K (right).

elements.content: In conclusion, we synthesized a novel peptide ligand for the 2D assembly of Ag­(I) ions in a crystal, which showed luminescence even at room temperature. Multiple Ag–Ag distances are presented by the assembled peptide ligands as a template. These Ag–Ag distances show different responses to external stimuli accompanying with anisotropic changes in the template peptide. This study indicates that the assembled structures of short peptide ligands provide a novel switchable platform for assembling metal ions. Such switchable systems could open up new opportunities for developing sophisticated solid-state functionalities through the combination of external stimuli (such as temperature, pressure, and electric field).
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, we synthesized a novel peptide ligand for the 2D assembly of Ag(I) ions in a crystal, which showed luminescence even at room temperature. Multiple Ag-Ag distances are presented by the assembled peptide ligands as a template. These Ag-Ag distances show different responses to external stimuli accompanying with anisotropic changes in the template peptide. This study indicates that the assembled structures of short peptide ligands provide a novel switchable platform for assembling metal ions. Such switchable systems could open up new opportunities for developing sophisticated solid-state functionalities through the combination of external stimuli (such as temperature, pressure, and electric field).

elements.content: Experimental procedures, additional structural data, and spectral data (UV–vis, IR, emission spectra) of the crystalline Ag­(I) complex. X-ray crystallographic information files (CIF) at various temperatures are available. Crystallographic information files are also available from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center (CCDC) upon request (http://www/ccdc.cam.ac.uk, CCDC deposition number –). This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org/.

metadata.title:
Selective Thermal Elongation of Metal–Metal
Distances in the Two-Dimensional Assembly of Ag(I) Ions Templated
by Assembled Peptide Ligands
